lines.text: Because at this very moment, this warehouse is being surrounded by one hundred cops with Doberman pinschers. Would you believe it? A hundred cops with Doberman pinschers.
I find that hard to believe.
Would you believe ten security guards and a bloodhound?
I don't think so.
How about a Boy Scout with rabies?
[last lines]
99, I love you better than the whole world. Would you believe it? The whole world.
Yes Max, I believe it.
[they kiss]
All right, Major, what happened? Why did we not get the Hottentot papers?
Errrrr...
We don't ERRRRRR here!
Mr. Smart, may I say that meeting you is the highlight of my entire career!
Thank you, Beamish! How long have you been with the company?
Three days!
Could you speak a little louder, sir? They're throwing dirt in my grave.
You met the President! What's he like?
Everything you'd expect him to be!
Oh, I'm sorry to hear that.
Smart, you appear to be in pretty good shape, do you work out?
I jog one hundred miles every day! Would you believe it? One hundred miles!
I find that hard to believe.
Would you believe fifty?
No!
How about two push ups and a deep breath?
Missed it by *that* much.
Oh, Max. You let him get away. Did you get a look at his face?
If that was his face he has a huge cleft in his chin!
What's our assignment? Find Hotentot?
13! How did you know that?
I still got my contacts, Max. I got a friend inside the White House, really inside. She's in the plumbing!
You mean you and Siegfried are triplets?
No, there are three of us.
You mean to tell me that you have another brother who looks exactly like you and Siegfried?
No, a sister.
I bet she has a tough time getting dates.
They can produce acid rain, destroy all our crops, and pollute our water.

[Incredulously]
You mean they can do that better than we're doing it now?
I can drown the city that houses your finest minds, your most brilliant intillects.

[to 99]
Well at least Washington is safe.
Ok, I'll go in and you cover me.
Max, I dont have a gun.
Eh, ok, then you go in and I'll cover you.
Max!
Eh, I've got a gun for you, 99.
[pulls open elbow-patch, takes out mini-gun]
Max this looks like a tootsie role with a trigger. What do you say when you use this, 'Put your finger up?'
Well, it might not look like much, 99, but when you attach this noiser to it...
Noiser?
...a bang becomes a boom.
What's up, sir?
The fate of the world, the President's blood presure and you! Sit down, sit down.

[on phone]
This is the single most important telephone call you will ever receive. The fate of the world depends upon you.

[on shoephone]
Could you hold that thought for a second sir, someone's coming.
[Max moves off as a coffin slides by]
He put the world on hold.
The Cone of Silence. It's an obsolete anti-bugging device.
Well, it's not really obsolete, sir. as a matter of fact, I bought one at the Control garage sale, it's hanging over my bed.
Over your bed?
I talk in my sleep.
Now Smart, remember, KAOS will do everything in it's power to try to stop you. You'll be in imminent danger and constant jeopardy, facing death at every turn.
And... loving it!
Where have you been keeping yourself?

[lying in a cabinet drawer]
Oh, here and there, just part-time spying now. Two weeks in a toilet in Talido, a voodoo drum in Haiti. That was kind of fun, like a vacation.

I am two years away from retiring and out of nowhere, KAOS is taken over by a corporate raider, a crazy man. Oh, the pressure, you have no idea what the pressure is like. I've got headaches, high blood pressure, insomnia, I'm a capitalist casualty, a merger victim!
We need you to come back to work for Control.
Sure, when you need me you come around. Otherwise I never hear from you. It really hurts, Max. I'm not made of stone, you know.
[hits his metal chest]
We have perfected a mini-camera that fits right into your nose. All you have to do is press this button on your jacket and your elbow will record what your nose sees.
Well, wouldn't it be better if my nose recorded what my elbow sees?
No.
No?
No.
No.
Simply because in your elbow patch compartment there is a mini recorder plus everything else you might need. A mini-magnet, a mini-gun and a mini-condom.
I'm curious. What use do we have for a mini-magnet?
All you need to know is in your mini-manual which is in your other elbow patch compartment.
We've got one week to save the world. Lucky it's this week, we set our clocks back on Sunday.
That gives us an extra hour.
Go to sleep, 99.
I can't.
Why not?
You're sitting on me.

[Max is holding a vase and a lamp and keeping a grandfatherclock from falling with his back]
Wait a minute. Eh. Do me a favor.

[pointing a gun at Max]
What?

[holds up the lamp and the vase]
Hold these while I read you your rights.
Max, was that man from KAOS?
How did you know, 99?
Remember Gruvnik?
Of course, Gruvnik the Spoiler!
Right. In 1969 he was traded by KAOS to THRUSH for a rookie killer and two minor-league muggers. That man was Beademeyer, one of the muggers.
Of course, I should've remembered his clammy hands.

[referring to Max and 99]
Commander, this man und this... number are mistaken.
I agree, 99. There's something rotten in Detroit.
That's Denmark, Max.
Oh. Well, things haven't been that great in Detroit either.
It's the old, old Trojan horse trick.
That could work... 99, are you sure this isn't your idea?
No, it was Max's.
Well, we'll just have to chalk this up to a precious waste of time... and chalk.
Shtarker, this is KAOS. We don't 'Yippie-yo-ka-yah' here.
Forgive me, I know we don't 'Yippie-yo-ka-yah' here.
Occasionally a strained 'Yahoo' is alright.
Max, I can't believe me, I'm all butterflies. Do you realize how long it's been since we've done something this exciting together?
What was wrong with Tuesday night?
How is mother?
Why ask now? You don't care. You never call, you never write.
How well I know that feeling...
Oh Max, I divulged too much. I didn't need to list all of your idiosyncrasies.
My idiosyncrasies?
Pages 127 to 145.
Why couldn't you just write a diet book like everybody else?

[Max holds up Tolstoy's War and Peace to block a KAOS agent with a knife]
Nobody gets through War and Peace!
Mr. Smart! That was my best brush with death so far.
[first lines]
Commander, it's Agent Beamish.
Verify.

[we see a skeleton X-ray]
It's him sir.
Activate the door.

[entering]
What's up, sir?
The fate of the world, the president's blood pressure, and you. Sit down.
The fate of the civilized world depends upon you.
What about our side, sir?
Believe me, it's not easy to send one of my men off on a mission that some of my Cabinet members have characterized as, one of certain death.
Certain death?
Yes, but in my opinion I have no other choice.
Could we get a second opinion?
Oh Max, how horrible.
Well he deserved it 99, he was nothing but a Kaos killer.
Sometimes I wonder if we're any better Max.
What are you talking about, 99? We have to kill and maim and destroy, we stand for everything that's good and fine and decent in the world.
